Sure, increasing accessibility for customers with specific needs can be achieved through several ways. Here are three examples:

1. Offering a wider range of sizes: Customers with larger or smaller feet may have difficulty finding running shoes that fit comfortably. By offering a wider range of sizes, the brand can cater to this group of customers and ensure they have a positive experience with the brand. This can be achieved by offering extended size options or by using custom-fit technology.
2. Catering to customers with orthotics: Customers who wear orthotics may have difficulty finding running shoes that are compatible with their inserts. By offering shoes that have a removable insole or a wider toe box, the brand can cater to this group of customers and ensure they have a comfortable and supportive experience.
3. Creating shoes for specific activities: Some customers have specific needs based on their running activities. For example, customers who participate in trail running may require shoes that have more aggressive tread patterns and better grip. By creating shoes designed specifically for these activities, the brand can cater to this group of customers and provide them with a better experience.

In summary, increasing accessibility for customers with specific needs can be achieved by offering a wider range of sizes, catering to customers with orthotics, and creating shoes for specific activities. This can help the brand to attract and retain customers who may have been overlooked by other brands in the market.
